text: hi this is Dean Deblois I'm the writer
director and executive producer of How
to Train Your Dragon 2 so this sequence
which is actually the second one in our
film introduces hiccup about as far away
from Berk as he can get it's meant to be
a kind of a playful fun sense of
boundless freedom which is really where
hiccup is in his life he's standing on
the cusp of adulthood and being tasked
with taking over for his father as the
new chief of Berk and yet he'd just
rather be out here playing in the clouds
with toothless finding new lands mapping
them and discovering new dragons along
the way we wanted it to be largely
dialogue free and just driven by the
music and so it has this great pulsing
energetic and euphoric sound which is
brought to us by Yan Zhi an Icelandic
singer-songwriter who is also the
frontman of cigarettes
I've done a couple films with Jonesy and
we actually asked him to do the end
credits song of the first film but this
time around we thought it would be fun
if he and John Powell were to
collaborate on a couple of pieces that
would be baked into the film this is the
first of the two and it's called where
no one goes pickups been busy in the
last five years designing all sorts of
cool little pieces of equipment that he
wears all over himself and he's
redesigned toothless's saddle so
everything's much more aerodynamic and
he carries on him all of the tools that
he uses to map new lands we wanted to
mask his his features so that we could
reveal them toward the end of the scene
and give him kind of a superhero quality
as as he's testing the world's first
flight suit it's meant to be a little
rusty but the idea was that they could
be independent and yet together and by
locking toothless's tail that could
glide alongside one another it seems
graceful and beautiful and hopefully is
has this kind of kinetic euphoric feel
to it but being that it's in the early
stages of its development it also ends
in a lot of scuffle and and mishap as we
see toward the end of the scene
camerawork in this film is actually
inspired by a lot of live-action
cinematography so we always try to make
it feel as kinetic and handheld as
possible there's a feature that we
wanted which was to have the sense that
there's an operator who can
overcompensate or try to follow the
characters but not quite get them all of
the time and it creates a believable
sense of real world physics that makes
our animated world seem that much more
credible
that's a locked up tail makes for some
pretty sloppy rescue maneuvers hey and
the whole scene builds toward the big
payoff which is to reveal what hiccup
looks like these five years later we're
very careful to keep the features that
make hiccup so winning as a character
and that includes his slight build and
gangly and of adorable dorky quality but
with it we wanted to give a sense of an
aspirational hero who's coming into his
